Iatrogenic suicidality - a case 
report
Dear Sir,
A 69-year-old recently retired bricklayer was referred to outpatient 
Consultation-Liaison (CL) Psychiatry 
for opinion and management of ‘terrible anxiety’ and suicidal ideation. 
He was receiving chemotherapy for 
a salivary duct carcinoma diagnosed 
2 months earlier. He had no significant history and had never been suicidal. Written consent was obtained 
to publish the case.
Three days prior to referral, he had 
been involuntarily admitted to a 
psychiatric inpatient unit after being 
found by police, at 11 pm, standing 
atop a cliff contemplating suicide. 
On review, he denied suicidal intent
but spoke of feeling ‘too stressed’ 
and having needed to ‘get some 
fresh air’. Given his recent cancer, a 
working diagnosis of ‘underlying 
depression’ was made. The following 
morning, he was discharged home 
with his wife. That afternoon he saw 
his GP who prescribed mirtazapine.
On assessment, the man described 
feeling ‘too much stress’ but struggled 
to qualify his experience. He denied 
any specific cognitions attached to his 
‘stress’, but voiced it was unrelenting 
and unbearable. He described ‘tension’ in his body – especially in the 
shoulders and abdomen. He felt restless, fidgety and reported he could not 
sit still (e.g. he was unable to sit for 
dinner or TV). He denied feeling 
pervasively low or overtly worried 
about his cancer but portrayed a sense 
of bodily inescapability and exhaustion. His sleep was disturbed, waking 
every 3–4 h with restlessness. He 
denied suicidal plans or intent but 
declared he ‘could not go on living 
like this’.
The patient had commenced chemotherapy 10 days earlier. He had 
been prescribed metoclopramide, 
10  mg thrice daily – his wife dutifully administered every dose. Onset 
of symptoms was 1–2 days later.
Mental state revealed a healthylooking man with a restless and distressed demeanour. He moved his 
feet several times and stood up midreview, pacing nearby as we continued the assessment. His affect was 
dysphoric and reactive with a limited range. There was no evidence 
of delirium, psychosis or mania.
Physical examination revealed a 
moderate tremor in both hands and 
mild rigidity and cogwheeling in his 
left upper limb (wrist and elbow). 
His gait was slow, with a stooped 
posture and no arm swing.
The impression was metoclopramideinduced extra-pyramidal side effects 
(EPSE) with severe akathisia and secondary suicidality. Metoclopramide 
was immediately ceased, and the 
patient given lorazepam to sleep that 
night. Within 3 days, he reported full 
resolution of the aforementioned 
symptoms, including all suicidal 
urges.
Akathisia has long been associated 
with suicide.1 Myriad psychotropics 
are causal, namely antipsychotics, but 
there are several non-psychotropic 
offenders—including anti-dopaminergic anti-emetics (e.g. metoclopramide).1 In one study, neurolepticinduced akathisia was correctly identified in only 26% of those afflicted.2
In another, in patients receiving 
chemotherapy (with anti-dopaminergic antiemetics), 50% met diagnostic criteria for akathisia, yet 75% said 
they wouldn’t have reported symptoms to clinicians.3 Prompt recognition and management of druginduced akathisia (psychotropic or 
otherwise) is critical to prevent iatrogenic harm and, potentially, suicide.
Disclosure
The author reports no conflict of interest. The author alone is 
responsible for the content and writing of the paper.

The impact of patient suicide 
on the psychiatrist
Dear Sir,
There is scant literature addressing 
this important area of our work, 
which for some can sit within the 
realms of taboo. Henry et al.1 propose a model that can be adopted to 
assist trainees and their supervisors 
in managing this profoundly distressing event. I recall no such guidelines being present at any stage in 
my training or subsequent tenure as 
a consultant, and as such she should 
be applauded for expanding the 
writing on this ineffable subject. A 
patient’s suicide can bring enormous 
distress to clinicians, and for some 
has influenced a change of career or

Lugg W. Iatrogenic suicidality - a case report. Australasian Psychiatry. 2021;29(6):705. DOI: 10.1177/10398562211014222

This spontaneous case was reported in the medical literature by a healthcare professional from the Australia and concerns a 69-year-old male patient, who experienced serious adverse reactions of drug induced extra-pyramidal, terrible anxiety, severe akathisia and secondary suicidality associated with metoclopramide. This patient retired bricklayer was referred to outpatient Consultation-Liaison (CL) Psychiatry for opinion and management of ‘terrible anxiety’ and suicidal ideation. He was receiving chemotherapy for a salivary duct carcinoma diagnosed 2 months earlier. He had no significant history and had never been suicidal.

Case was reported from Australia.
